Graphical abstract Highlights ► Microporous carbon nitride material catalyzes Knoevenagel condensation reactions. ► Various aldehydes and active methylene compounds can be catalyzed effectively. ► Catalysts readily usable for the catalytic reactions without any pretreatment. Microporous graphitic carbon nitride (CN-Mic) material has been prepared using carbon tetrachloride and ethylene diamine as precursors, and a siliceous microporous MCM-22 as a hard template. A series of Knoevenagel condensation reactions have been performed over the CN-Mic sample, and the influences of reaction conditions on the corresponding catalytic behavior have been investigated. The results showed that the CN-Mic material exhibited high catalytic activity and versatility for the condensation reactions. XPS and FT-IR analysis reveal a high abundance of the N-containing groups located on the surface of CN-Mic, which accounts for the superior catalytic activity of the carbon nitride material as a promising new type of heterogeneous Lewis base catalyst for the condensation reactions. It is also revealed that the activity of CN-Mic is much higher than those obtained over mesoporous g-CN materials. Meanwhile, the catalytic results of CN-Mic compared favorably with those of other g-CN materials for Knoevenagel reactions reported previously. In addition, a mechanism for the CN-Mic catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation was tentatively proposed. Keywords Carbon nitride Knoevenagel condensation Base catalyst 1 Introduction Knoevenagel condensation (the reaction between an aldehyde and an active methylene-containing reagent) is one of the most primary processes to synthesize valuable α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds that are widely utilized in the pharmaceutical industry [1,2]. Conventionally, Knoevenagel condensation reactions proceed homogenously in the presence of various base catalysts [3], which can activate the methylene-containing reagent by abstracting an acidic proton from it. These catalysts are mainly nitrogen-containing molecules such as aliphatic amines, urea and piperidine or their corresponding ammonium salts and amino acids [4]. Notwithstanding their high catalytic activity, the thorny issues associated with the separation and recycling of the catalyst cannot meet the increasing demand on green and sustainable catalysis nowadays. Several heterogeneous inorganic salts, such as phosphates and halides, have also been reported as catalysts in the Knoevenagel condensation. However, the use of such materials leads to metal contamination of the products [5]. Recently, ionic liquid or organic amine immobilized mesoporous silica materials have been extensively used as base catalysts [6]. Nevertheless, the drawback of limited number of active sites along with easy leaching of anchored catalysts restrains a further catalytic application of these materials. Owing to the increasing attention toward the development of green and sustainable heterogeneous catalysis, it is imperative to search a more efficient and sustainable catalyst for Knoevenagel condensation process. As one of the most appealing and promising metal-free materials, graphitic carbon nitride (g-CN) has recently received a great deal of attention in many research fields [7,8]. The success of g-CN is largely attributed to its unique combination of various physicochemical properties. Of particular note is that the incorporation of N atoms into the C nanostructures endows g-CN with plenty of basic sites in the forms of amine groups, etc. [9], which dictates an intrinsically basic function. Hence, the exploitation of g-CN has opened new and exciting opportunities in the fields of base catalysis. Park et al. [5] reported mesoporous g-CN as metal-free base catalyst for Knoevenagel condensation reactions, wherein g-CN materials exhibited efficiently catalytic activity under microwave irradiation, affording high yields of 75–95% within short time of 12min. Wang et al. [10] reported the synthesis of high-surface-area g-CN using cyanamide as precursor. After the pretreatment of deprotonation by tBuOK or KOH solution, the g-CN materials demonstrated higher catalytic activity for various Knoevenagel condensation as well as transesterification reactions. Although the results above have evidenced the catalytic potential of g-CN materials in Knoevenagel condensation reactions and other organocatalysis processes, it should be mentioned that the high catalytic results were achieved under an assisted condition or pretreatment, i.e. microwave irradiation or deprotonation. In fact, poor catalytic yields were obtained if using bare g-CN materials without any promoting condition. From both practical and sustainable points of view, it is highly desired to develop a readily usable and effective g-CN catalyst capable of facilitating Knoevenagel condensation under mild conditions. Herein, we employ microporous g-CN material (CN-Mic) as a catalyst for a series of Knoevenagel condensation. The catalytic results have revealed that CN-Mic can be used readily without any assisted reaction condition or catalyst pretreatment, and exhibited high efficiency for the condensation between various aldehydes and methylene group-containing compounds. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of CN-Mic has been compared in detail with those obtained over other g-CN materials reported previously. In addition, a possible mechanism for the CN-Mic catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation has been proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation CN-Mic sample was prepared according to the established templating-assisted method [11]. In a typical procedure, 2.0g of MCM-22 powder was added into the previously well-mixed solution containing 6.0g of carbon tetrachloride (CTC) and 3.6g of ethylenediamine (EDA). The mixture above was then heated at 90°C for 6h under refluxing to induce polymerization of the precursors, followed by drying at 50°C overnight. The obtained dark-brown solid was heated from room temperature to 600°C at a ramp of 3°Cmin−1 and kept in 600°C for another 5h under argon atmosphere. Finally, the CN-Mic sample was recovered after washing with NH4HF2 aqueous solution (4molL−1) to remove the template. The yield of resultant sample was around 0.7g. 2.2 Samples characterization Structural analysis of MCM-22 and CN-Mic samples was carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (XRD) equipped with a graphite monochromator, operating at 40kV and 40mA and employing nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5418Å). Nitrogen adsorption at −196°C was measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 after the samples were degassed (1.33×10−2 Pa) at 150°C for 4h. The specific surface area (S BET) was calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore diameter and pore size distribution were determined from the Horvath–Kawazoe (H–K) method. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the CN-Mic sample was measured using a Perkin-Elmer PHI 5000C spectrometer working in the constant analyzer energy mode with Mg Kα radiation as the excitation source. The carbonaceous C 1s line (284.6eV) was used as the reference to calibrate the binding energies (BE). FT-IR spectrum of the sample was collected on a Bruker Tensor spectrometer via the usual KBr pellet technique. Elementary analysis (EA) was performed with EA2400 II (PerkinElmer) instrument to determine the carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, and sulfur content of the sample. 2.3 Catalytic test Catalytic tests for Knoevenagel condensation reaction were carried in a two-neck round bottomed flask (25mL). 10mmol of aldehyde, 10mmol of methylene group-containing nitrile, 0.5mL of n-decane as internal standard, and 5mL of solvent (CH3CN or n-butanol as desired) were mixed well. 100mg of CN-Mic sample was added into the mixture and the catalytic tests were performed at 90°C for 4h. After the reaction, the mixture was centrifuged and analyzed by GC–MS. The filtered catalyst was washed with ethanol for two times, dried overnight, and then investigated for its next running. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization The powder XRD patterns of the microporous CN-Mic material together with the parent zeolite template (MCM-22) are shown in Fig. 1 . In sharp contrast with the template, which exhibits a highly intense diffraction peaks, the CN-Mic sample prepared via nanocasting method demonstrates broad and weak diffraction peaks. The peak located at 2θ =25.5° corresponding to the (002) diffraction (interlayer of the graphitic sheets) with a d spacing of 3.50Å is similar to the d spacing obtained in the bulk carbon nitride (d =3.36Å) materials reported previously [11,9]. This indicates the formation of turbostratic ordering of carbon and nitrogen atoms in the CN graphene layers of CN-Mic [12]. Fig. 2 shows the N2 adsorption isotherms and the corresponding pore distribution of the parent MCM-22 sieve and CN-Mic sample. According to the IUPAC classification, both isotherms are of type I, which is characteristic of uniform microporous solids. The steep uptake in the adsorption branch of CN-Mic below p/p°=0.02 indicates an existence of the microporous structures after the removal of the template. Unlike MCM-22, the CN-Mic sample demonstrates an apparent capillary condensation at p/p°>0.2, reflecting that CN-Mic also possesses considerable mesopores besides micropores, e.g. interparticle voids. As pointed out by Bao et al. [13], the occurrence of mesoporosity could be attributed to interparticle voids. Meanwhile, parts of MCM-22 remain unfilled during the polymerization of precursors, and after HF extracting, large mesopores are created. The surface areas and pore information of the two samples are summarized in Table 1 . It is noteworthy that, unlike those pervasively mesoporous size distribution methods, H–K method is derived independently from the Kelvin equation and the calculation of pore distribution is based on the very low pressure (p/p°<0.01) [11,13]. As shown in the inset of Fig. 2, the pore size of CN-Mic is 0.71nm, larger than that of its parent template. Moreover, the surface area and the micropore volume of CN-Mic are 212m2 g−1 and 0.06cm3 g−1, appreciably lower than those of MCM-22 (Table 1). XPS was performed to analyze the surface information of the CN-Mic sample. As illustrated in Fig. 3a, the main composition of the sample are carbon and nitrogen, accompanied with a small amount of oxygen and fluorine which may come from trace of water and HF adsorbed on the surface of CN-Mic. The absence of silicon or aluminum confirms that the template has been almost thoroughly removed by NH4HF2 etching. Furthermore, detailed resolution spectra of C 1s and N 1s were collected to further investigate the chemical bonding of the CN-Mic sample. The C 1s peak (Fig. 4b) can be deconvoluted into four bands at 289.3, 287.5, 285.7, and 284.1eV, respectively. The band centering at 284.1eV can be assigned to pure graphitic sites in a CN matrix [14,15], while the peak at 285.7eV can be attributed to the sp 2 carbon atom bonded to N inside the aromatic ring [16]. The highest peaks located 287.5 and 289.3eV suggest the formation of sp 3-hybridized and sp 2-hybridized carbon in the aromatic ring attached to NH2 groups, respectively [17]. Additionally, two peaks centered at 400.2 and 397.8eV, are observed in the N 1s spectrum (Fig. 4c), which corresponds to the N atoms trigonally bonded to sp 2 carbon in an amorphous CN network and nitrogen sp 2-bonded to carbon, respectively [15]. Moreover, FT-IR spectrometry was applied to analyze the bulk chemical information of CN-Mic. Fig. 3d shows three major bands centered at 3423, 1590, and 1286cm−1. The bands at 1286 and 1590cm−1 are assigned to aromatic CN stretching bands and aromatic ring modes, respectively, while the broad peak at 3423cm−1 is assigned to the stretching mode of NH groups in the aromatic ring and/or residual water molecule [12,13]. According to the information, it can be inferred that that CN-Mic are mainly comprised of pyridine and benzene rings interconnected by nitrogen atoms, in line with those reported in literatures [14,18]. In addition, calculated by elemental analysis (EA), the bulk composition of CN-Mic is C3.97N1H1.61 and the amount of N (22.1wt%) thereof is remarkably higher than those of reported N-doped carbon materials [19] as well as that microporous carbon nitride prepared by ZSM-5 template [13]. 3.2 Catalyst activity Initially, benzaldehyde and malononitrile are chosen as mode substrates to examine the catalytic activity of CN-Mic for Knoevenagel condensation reactions. The influence of the reaction temperature on the catalytic activity was first investigated (Fig. 4a). With increase of temperature, the conversion of reagent increases drastically from 70 to 90 and smoothly over 90°C. At the elevated temperature of 100°C, the conversion is up to 93.6%. On the other hand, the selectivities to the products (2-benzylidenemalononitrile) at different reaction temperatures are all around 95%. The byproduct is mainly benzoic acid that originates from the auto-oxidation of benzaldehyde under ambient atmosphere. Fig. 4b plots the conversion and selectivity as a function of reaction time. At 0.5h, the reaction processes with a moderate conversion of 56%. Upon prolonging the reaction over 4h, the conversion reaches its maximum. Regarding the effect of reaction conditions on their corresponding catalytic performance, the temperature of 90°C and reaction time of 4h were chosen as optimal reaction conditions for the further catalytic investigation. The effect of the amount of catalyst on the catalytic behavior has also been evaluated (Fig. 5a). Blank experiment shows that almost no benzaldehyde or malononitrile converts into the target molecule in the absence of the catalyst. Upon increasing the amount of catalyst, a remarkable improvement of the conversion is clearly observed as expected. Meanwhile, it is also found that the selectivity is sensitive to the amount of catalyst. Taking into account of the auto-oxidation of benzaldehyde, higher concentration of base catalyst could suppress the formation of the byproduct (benzoic acid) [20], thereby offering a spontaneous increment at the conversion together with selectivity. A series of repetitive experiments were performed to test the reusability of the catalyst and reproducibility of catalytic performance. In each cycle, CN-Mic was recovered by filtration and then rinsed with ethanol. After drying, the catalyst was reused for the next run. The catalytic behavior of the condensation reaction during the first consecutive five runs is displayed in Fig. 5b. The selectivities obtained in these cycles are all above 95%. In the case of the conversion, a distinct decrease of ca 10% is observed in the first recycling, which is mainly due to the leaching of N-containing fragments (NH2 or N) located at the brink of the graphitic layers [9,18]. In spite of the initial decline, the subsequent running tests present a stable catalytic activity, implying the CN-Mic can be served as a heterogeneous and stable catalyst for Knoevenagel condensation. To probe the versatility of CN-Mic for Knoevenagel condensation reaction, various aldehyde and methylene group-containing nitride with a molar ratio of 1:1 in the presence of CN-Mic were studied and the results are summarized in Table 2 . The reactions between benzaldehyde/4-chorobenzaldehyde/4-methoxybenzaldehyde and malononitrile afforded high yields of the corresponding products (entries 1, 3 and 4). Besides aromatic aldehyde, aliphatic aldehyde such as pentanal, and furfural could undergo the condensation with malononitrile, giving a final product with high efficiency (entries 5 and 6). It is worthy to note that furfural is a typical biomass-derived compound. Furthermore, different active methylene compounds were compared for Knoevenagel condensation at the same catalytic conditions. As listed in Table 2, ethyl cyanoacetate presents less reactivity than malononitrile (entries 2 and 7), possibly because the electron withdrawing ability of the substituent carbonyl group is weaker than that of the CN group. However, a high yield could be retrieved if the reaction was carried out under a protic solvent such as n-butanol (entry 8). For a comparative purpose, we have also prepared three mesoporous g-CN materials adopting SBA-15, mesoporous cellular silica foam (MCF), and commercial nanosized silica sphere (∼15nm) as template. The preparation routes and the corresponding textural properties of synthesized CN-SBA-15, CN-MCF, and CN-SiO2-15nm materials are given in the supporting information. As depicted in Fig. 6 , CN-Mic demonstrates superior catalytic conversion to its counterparts under the same catalytic condition. The order of the conversion of the four g-CN catalysts is as follows: CN-Mic>CN-MCF>CN-SBA-15>CN-SiO2-15nm. Considering this fact, the catalytic activity for Knoevenagel condensation is necessarily associated with the porous structures (Fig. 6 and Table 3 ) of the g-CN materials. Bearing in the mind that the condensation reaction is catalyzed in the presence of base catalyst, to gain further insight into the base nature of the four porous g-CN samples above in relation to their corresponding catalytic activity, the N/C molar ratios are listed in Fig. 7 . Although CN-SBA-15 and CN-MCF with a pore size of 4–5nm have higher total N/C ratios (calculated by EA), the conversions are moderate, approximately 60%. However, it is found the catalytic activity correlates well with the corresponding superficial N/C ratios (based on XPS profiles). This points to that the N species located over the surface, rather than bulk, of g-CN contributes directly to the catalytic activity. In general, the reported g-CN materials can be categorized into two groups. The first species of g-CN are prepared by thermal condensation using cyanamide [21,22], dicyandiamide [23] or melamine [24] as precursor, and the C/N ratios of such compounds are close to the theoretical ratio of g-C3N4 (0.75). As suggested by Kroke et al. [25], the tectonic units of 2D π-conjugated g-C3N4 sheets are tri-s-triazine (Scheme 1a) rings linked by N bridges. Featured with a band gap of 2.7eV (consistent with yellow color) [26,27], g-C3N4 has been intensively used as a robust photocatalyst for water splitting [28], degradation of pollutants [29], etc. Alternatively, the other species of g-CN materials posses a substantially higher content of carbon, which makes the solids pure black [13,30]. Typically, the precursors used for synthesis of the material are CTC) and EDA [31]. Unlike those of yellow g-C3N4, the motifs of the second species of g-CN materials are speculated as N-substituted graphitic rings and/or cross-linking of graphitic CN planes (Scheme 1b) [31]. Table 4 summarizes the catalytic performances of Knoevenagel condensation reactions over various g-CN materials; the information has covered almost all recently reported results involving the g-CN-catalyzed Knoevenagel reactions. Mpg-C3N4 (entries 1 and 2) and MCN (entry 3) were prepared by thermal condensation using cyanamide and melamine as precursor, respectively, and the materials belong to the first species of g-CN, as noted previously. Although the yellow g-C3N4 materials possess a large quantity of N atoms, there is no electron localization in π state in perfect carbon nitride sheets [26]. Indeed, when the g-C3N4 materials are employed as catalysts for base-catalyzed reactions, only surface defects of terminal amino groups and bridging N atoms [20] (originated from incompletely condensation) could serve as Lewis-base-type active sites. Under this circumstance, the pristine g-C3N4 materials need assisted treatment or special reaction condition, such as deprotonation and microwave irradiation to inspire their catalytic potential. On the other hand, the black g-CN materials fabricated using CTC and EDA as precursor could be used readily as catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation reactions. Compare with bulk CN sample fabricated without template (entry 8), microporous CN-Mic catalyst (entry 7) provides a considerably higher conversion of aldehyde, which could be owing to the introduction of porous structures as well as accessible surface area. In addition, other base catalysts, including mesoporous poly(benzimidazole) (mp-PBI, entry 4), N-containing MCM-48 ([CTA]-MCM-41, entry 5), and metal organic frameworks (CuBTC, entry 6) for Knoevenagel condensation as a base catalyst is also listed in Table 4. Taking into account the final conversions and catalytic conditions, the catalytic activity of CN-Mic is obviously superior to that obtained in any other catalyst. Scheme 2 depicts a possible mechanism for Knoevenagel condensation catalyzed over the microporous carbon nitride. The active sites of the catalyst, CN-Mic, can be attributed to Lewis-base-type nitrogen species located in the CN matrixes, as discussed in the XPS and FT-IR characterization. First, an acidic proton is abstracted from the active methylene group by a Lewis-base site [35], yielding a stable anion. Spontaneously, the original base site is transformed into a protonated site (conjugate acid). Subsequently, this anion makes nucleophilic attack to the carbonyl-carbon atom of the aldehyde, forming an oxyanion. After abstracting H+ from the protonated site of CN-Mic and eliminating a molecule of H2O, the oxyanion turns into the corresponding condensation product. Meanwhile, the CN-Mic catalyst is regenerated. 4 Conclusion In summary, microporous carbon nitride, CN-Mic has been prepared using MCM-22 sieve as template and investigated as a heterogeneous base catalyst for Knoevenagel condensation. The catalytic results exemplified by various kinds of substrates have shown that the CN-Mic sample demonstrates efficient activity. The yield obtained was over 80% and the catalyst can be reused at least five runs without appreciable loss in catalytic activities. The catalytic active sites could be attributed to Lewis-base-type nitrogen species. We envision that the study constitutes an insight for further applications of porous carbon nitride materials toward metal-free and heterogeneous base organocatalysis, e.g. aldol-condensation between biomass-derived aldehyde and ketone, and synthesis of biodiesel via transesterification. coredata.dc:description: Microporous graphitic carbon nitride (CN-Mic) material has been prepared using carbon tetrachloride and ethylene diamine as precursors, and a siliceous microporous MCM-22 as a hard template. A series of Knoevenagel condensation reactions have been performed over the CN-Mic sample, and the influences of reaction conditions on the corresponding catalytic behavior have been investigated. The results showed that the CN-Mic material exhibited high catalytic activity and versatility for the condensation reactions. XPS and FT-IR analysis reveal a high abundance of the N-containing groups located on the surface of CN-Mic, which accounts for the superior catalytic activity of the carbon nitride material as a promising new type of heterogeneous Lewis base catalyst for the condensation reactions. It is also revealed that the activity of CN-Mic is much higher than those obtained over mesoporous g-CN materials. Meanwhile, the catalytic results of CN-Mic compared favorably with those of other g-CN materials for Knoevenagel reactions reported previously. In addition, a mechanism for the CN-Mic catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation was tentatively proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Microporous carbon nitride as an effective solid base catalyst for Knoevenagel condensation reactions
